word.entryDescription: the state of there being too many people living in a place
word.entryExample: Overpopulation is a worry on this small island.

word.entryDescription: weighing too much or being too fat
word.entryExample: Herbie is a stocky man – perhaps a little overweight.

word.entryDescription: a bird with a flat face and large eyes that hunts for small animals, usually at night
word.entryExample: Owls like to sleep during the day.

word.entryDescription: belonging to somebody
word.entryExample: They would like to have their own property with a front and back yard and a 2-car garage.

word.entryDescription: used with the numbers 1 to 12 to show that the time is exactly on the hour
word.entryExample: I go to work at nine o'clock.

word.entryDescription: used to refer to a time after 12 midday but before 12 midnight
word.entryExample: We think the plane will arrive at around 5:00 p.m.

word.entryDescription: something covered in paper or in a box often sent by post
word.entryExample: William was excited when the postman gave him a big package.

word.entryDescription: put into a box, bag, or other kind of packaging
word.entryExample: The availability of packaged snacks (like crisps), ready meals and microwave ovens means that people can eat at any time of day.

word.entryDescription: the box, bag, wrapping, etc that goods are sold in
word.entryExample: For a while, the cost of materials for packaging was more expensive than the food they contained.

word.entryDescription: food (e.g. sandwiches, fruit) that you take with you to work, school etc for lunch
word.entryExample: Which do you prefer to have – school dinners or packed lunch?

word.entryDescription: a thick flat object made of cloth, plastic or rubber, used to protect something, or to make something more comfortable
word.entryExample: Rollerbladers often wear protective pads on their elbows and knees.

word.entryDescription: a medicine removing or reducing pain
word.entryExample: My friend gave me painkillers and took me to the nearest hospital.

word.entryDescription: to make a picture using paint
word.entryExample: Paint some pink flowers on your bowl.

word.entryDescription: a picture made with paint
word.entryExample: There's a very big painting on the wall next to the window.

word.entryDescription: two similar things belonging together
word.entryExample: I've bought him a new pair of trainers.

word.entryDescription: a big grand building usually designed for a king or queen
word.entryExample: The king isn't in the palace at the moment.

word.entryDescription: having skin of a light colour or of a colour lighter than normal
word.entryExample: My skin is pale and my eyes and chin are much too big.

word.entryDescription: the inside part of your hand in which you hold things
word.entryExample: The old woman looked at my palm and told me the future.

word.entryDescription: a metal round container with a long handle you use for cooking food
word.entryExample: My mum fries eggs in a pan.

word.entryDescription: a large black and white animal like a bear that lives in China and eats mostly bamboo
word.entryExample: Pandas live in China.

word.entryDescription: thin, flat material made from crushed wood or cloth, used for writing, printing, or drawing on
word.entryExample: Did you remember to buy some paper in the shop?

word.entryDescription: very similar and often happening at the same time
word.entryExample: These two sentences are parallel in structure.

word.entryDescription: of or relating to the Paralympics (an international sporting event for disabled people)
word.entryExample: He's one of Britain's paralympic champions.

word.entryDescription: an item that has been wrapped in paper or put in a special envelope, so that it can be sent by post
word.entryExample: Where can I buy a stamp and send a parcel?

word.entryDescription: to forgive somebody for something they have said or done (used when you want to be polite)
word.entryExample: Pardon me for interrupting you.

word.entryDescription: your mother and father
word.entryExample: My parents are both teachers.

word.entryDescription: a tropical bird with a hooked beak and usually colourful feathers, which can be trained to copy human speech
word.entryExample: Polly the parrot wanted to look for treasure.

word.entryDescription: for less than the whole time it is usual to work, study, etc
word.entryExample: She works part-time in a restaurant.

word.entryDescription: a social event where people get together to have fun by eating, drinking, dancing, etc
word.entryExample: Can you come to my party on Saturday?

word.entryDescription: a person who is walking past a place by chance
word.entryExample: Passers-by stopped to see what happened.

word.entryDescription: breathing in smoke from other people's cigarettes
word.entryExample: It is thought that passive smoking can damage your health.

word.entryDescription: a document which proves who you are, and which you need in order to leave one country and get into another
word.entryExample: Can I see your passports, please?

word.entryDescription: a place at an airport, port or border where your passport is checked
word.entryExample: When we got to the passport control, I couldn't find my passport.

word.entryDescription: a secret combination of letters, numbers or symbols which you must sometimes type into a computer for the purposes of security
word.entryExample: First of all I have to switch my computer on and key in my password when it starts working.

word.entryDescription: beyond; farther on than
word.entryExample: Go straight on through the shopping centre, past the post office.

word.entryDescription: a food made from flour, eggs and water, and made into different shapes
word.entryExample: In Italy we eat pasta very often.

word.entryDescription: something you enjoy doing in your free time
word.entryExample: One of my favourite pastimes is hiking.

word.entryDescription: a narrow road used for walking
word.entryExample: The man walked up the path and knocked on the front door.

word.entryDescription: somebody who is receiving medical care or treatmen
word.entryExample: Nowadays, doctors give their patients medicine to stop pain during surgery.

word.entryDescription: a hard surface outside a house where people often sit
word.entryExample: In my ideal home there would be a patio so that I could sit outside and enjoy the view, and a path leading down to the shore.

word.entryDescription: to give money when buying something or in exchange for a service
word.entryExample: I didn't have any cash, but I was able to pay for the tickets by card.

word.entryDescription: to listen to, look at, or think about someone or something very carefully
word.entryExample: You have to pay attention to detail.

word.entryDescription: the equipment or people in a space vehicle
word.entryExample: For most of his life, Steve Bennett has wanted to build rockets capable of carrying a significant payload into space.

word.entryDescription: (=personal computer) a computer that is used by one person at a time
word.entryExample: I had to type up my report again after my PC crashed.

word.entryDescription: classes in which students do and study sport and physical exercise
word.entryExample: You exercise or play sport in physical education or PE for short.

word.entryDescription: a very small round green vegetable
word.entryExample: I'd like peas with my fish and chips.

word.entryDescription: quiet, calm and free of worry
word.entryExample: I would prefer to live in the suburbs where it's cleaner, quieter and more peaceful.

word.entryDescription: a period of time when a country is not fighting a war
word.entryExample: In peacetime the Red Cross works to improve public health and prevent the spread of disease.

word.entryDescription: a round fruit with a narrow top, a thin green skin and white flesh
word.entryExample: There are pears on the tree in our garden.

word.entryDescription: a long thin object with ink inside it that you use for writing and drawing on paper
word.entryExample: Can I use your pen?
